bioghist.p: Frederick Mosteller (1916-2006) was one of the premier statisticians of his generation. He received his master's degree from the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University) in 1939. In 1946, he received his Ph.D. from Princeton University, where he worked with statisticians Samuel Wilks and John Tukey. The same year, he joined the faculty of Harvard University in the social relations department. He was the first chairman of Harvard's statistics department, remaining in that role until 1971. He retired in 1987 as the chairman of the department of health policy and management. Mosteller applied mathematical theories to the analysis of educational development and assessment, medical practices, sports, and other fields. One notable study was a statistical analysis of the Federalist papers to settle a question of authorship.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of Frederick Mosteller. The papers in this collection document Mosteller's statistical inquiry in the areas of educational assessment, bias in social research, authorship analysis, quantitative expressions of probability, sports, coincidence, and variance analysis. Materials include: reprints of Mosteller's articles; memoranda on National Science Foundation-funded projects; notes, correspondence, photocopied reference articles, and drafts for various studies; awards, certificates, and honorary degrees; and a copy of Mosteller's master's thesis on rank correlation. The collection also includes Mosteller's academic gown and regalia.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
